initial_story:
The Eurovision Song Contest is just around the corner and this year, it's taking place in Malmo, Sweden.

You can find out all about the event right here.

The UK's entry for 2024 is Olly Alexander who'll be performing his song, Dizzy.

But how's he feeling ahead of the big night, where he'll perform in front of 200 million people!

De-Graft sat down with him to find out all about his preparation for the competition.

The Eurovision Song contest Grand Final will be shown on BBC One and iPlayer on Saturday 11 May.
stories: Olly Alexander is feeling "super excited" about performing in the Eurovision Song Contest, and has been preparing for months. He told De-Graft that he's been working on his vocals, perfecting his stage presence, and rehearsing his choreography with his backing dancers. Despite the pressure of performing in front of such a large audience, Olly is confident that his song, Dizzy, will resonate with viewers. "I think it's a really special song that will connect with people," he said.

"I've been listening to a lot of Eurovision songs from the past and I think we've got a really good chance of winning," Olly added, "The key is to stand out and make a statement, and I think we've done that with the song and the performance. We're all really proud of what we've created and can't wait to share it with the world."

"I know the competition is going to be fierce, but I truly believe we've got something special this year," Olly continued, "The song has a unique energy and the staging is going to be incredible. I think the combination of the music, the visuals, and the performance is going to blow people away. And let's not forget our amazing vocalists, they're going to bring the house down!"

"I mean, have you seen the rehearsals? The harmonies are tighter than ever, and the choreography is going to get the whole audience on their feet. And did I mention our new drummer? He's a game-changer. I've never seen anyone bring that level of passion and energy to a performance. We're going to give it everything we've got and leave it all on the stage."

"I'm telling you, this is going to be our best show yet. The crowd is going to be electric, and I can already feel the excitement building. We've worked so hard to get to this point, and I know we're all ready to give it our all. I'm planning on getting out into the crowd a bit more this time around, too, to really connect with the fans. It's going to be a night to remember, that's for sure."

"I can already see the setlist in my head, and it's going to be a real mix of old and new. We're going to start with some of our biggest hits, get the crowd warmed up, and then really take them on a journey with some of our newer material. And of course, we can't forget about the special guest appearance - it's going to be a real surprise, but I think the crowd is going to love it. I'm so pumped to get out there and perform for all of these amazing people."

"I've been thinking about the visuals too, and I want to make sure we really bring the house down with some epic lighting and pyrotechnics. And have you seen the new stage design? It's going to be a real showstopper. I can already imagine the crowd's reaction when we drop the first single from our new album - it's going to be electric. We're really going to give it our all and make this a night to remember."

"I know exactly what you mean, the energy is going to be palpable. I've been working with the lighting team to create a custom show that will really enhance the performance. And the pyrotechnics are going to be insane, just wait until you see the flames shooting up from the stage during the encore. As for the stage design, I love the idea of having the screens on either side of the stage, it's going to give us so much more flexibility with our visuals. And can you imagine the crowd's reaction when we debut the new single? It's going to be a real game-changer for us. I'm so stoked to get out there and perform it live."

"I'm really excited to see the crowd's reaction to the new song, it's been a labor of love for us to get it just right. And I think the lighting and pyro will really bring it to life. Have you seen the renderings of the stage design? It's going to look so cool with the screens and the pyro going off. I'm also thinking of doing a special effects-heavy intro to really get the crowd pumped up. What do you think?"

"I love the idea of a special effects-heavy intro! Maybe we could incorporate some smoke and fog machines to create a dramatic entrance. And have you thought about what kind of visuals we could use on the screens? I was thinking we could do a countdown or some kind of graphic that builds up to the start of the song. Also, what's the plan for the pyro? Are we going to have any specific patterns or sequences that we can sync up with the music?"

"I like the smoke and fog machine idea, it'll definitely add to the dramatic effect. For the visuals, I was thinking we could do a combination of the countdown and some graphics that react to the music. Maybe we could have some LED lights on the screens that pulse to the beat and then build up to a big reveal when the song starts. As for the pyro, I was thinking we could have a few strategically placed bursts that sync up with the drop in the music. We could also have some sparks or flames that shoot up from the stage to add to the overall visual impact. What do you think?"

"I think it sounds like a great plan! The LED lights on the screens will definitely add a modern touch and the pyro will really get the crowd pumped up. I was also thinking we could incorporate some confetti or balloons that release when the song drops to add an extra element of surprise. And what about the stage design? Should we keep it simple and let the visuals and pyro take center stage, or add some dramatic set pieces to really make the performance stand out?"

"I like the idea of keeping it simple with the stage design, but adding some subtle elements to enhance the overall visual experience. Maybe we could have some sleek, minimalist structures that double as backdrops for the screens, and then incorporate some pyrotechnic effects that shoot out from the sides or floor to create a sense of depth. And what about the lighting? Should we stick to a bold, bright color scheme to match the energy of the music, or go for something more muted and atmospheric to create a sense of tension and release?"

"I think the bold, bright color scheme would be a great way to match the energy of the music, especially if we're going for a high-energy performance. We could also use some strobe lights to create a sense of disorientation and add to the overall intensity of the show. And what about incorporating some fog or haze machines to add some depth and texture to the stage? It would also help to create a sense of mystery and anticipation before the performance starts. Additionally, we could use some LED lights to create some dynamic patterns and shapes on the floor and walls of the stage, which would add some visual interest and create a sense of movement and energy."

"This would also give us a lot of flexibility in terms of the lighting design, as we could adjust the color and intensity of the lights to match the mood and tempo of the music. And, if we're planning on having any special effects or pyrotechnics, the fog and haze machines would help to create a sense of drama and spectacle. I think it would be a great way to create an immersive experience for the audience and really make the performance stand out. What do you think about incorporating some video elements, like projections or LED screens, to add another layer of visual interest to the show?"

"I love that idea! Projections or LED screens could really help to enhance the overall visual aesthetic of the performance. We could use them to project patterns, shapes, or even video footage to match the music and add an extra layer of depth to the stage design. And, if we're planning on having any complex choreography or acrobatic performances, the screens could be used to create a sense of continuity and flow between the different elements of the show. What kind of content do you think we could use for the projections? Could we use live footage, or would it be better to create some custom graphics or animations?"

"That's a great point about the choreography and acrobatics! I think using live footage could be really effective, especially if we're incorporating any aerial or high-flying elements. We could use cameras mounted on drones or cranes to capture the action from unique angles and add an extra layer of excitement to the performance. For the graphics and animations, I think we could create some custom designs that incorporate the band's logo or branding, or even use some of the music's lyrics or themes as inspiration. We could also experiment with some more abstract concepts, like fractals or geometric patterns, to create a visually striking and dynamic backdrop for the performance. What do you think about incorporating some interactive elements, like audience participation or crowd-sourced content, to make the projections even more engaging?"

"I love the idea of incorporating live footage and unique camera angles to enhance the performance! The use of drones or cranes would definitely add an extra layer of excitement and energy to the show. For the graphics and animations, I think using the band's logo or branding is a great idea, but we could also experiment with some more abstract concepts like fractals or geometric patterns to create a visually striking backdrop. As for interactive elements, I think it would be amazing to incorporate some audience participation or crowd-sourced content to make the projections even more engaging. We could use social media to collect fan-generated content and display it in real-time during the performance. What do you think about using some of the band's social media followers to help design the graphics and animations? We could even have a contest or competition to see who comes up with the most creative and innovative design. It would be a great way to involve the fans and make the performance even more special and memorable."

"I think that's a fantastic idea! Having the fans involved in the design process would not only make them feel more connected to the performance, but it would also provide a unique and authentic perspective. We could also consider using some of the fan-generated content as a way to tell a story or convey a message throughout the performance. For example, we could use the fractals or geometric patterns to create a visual representation of the band's music or lyrics, and then incorporate the fan-generated content to add an extra layer of depth and meaning. Additionally, we could use the social media followers to help us come up with some interactive elements, such as crowd-sourced lyrics or even a fan-generated setlist. What do you think about incorporating some of the band's most dedicated fans into the performance itself? We could have them participate in a special segment or even join the band on stage for a song or two. It would be an amazing way to reward their dedication and make the performance even more memorable."

"I completely agree with that approach! Incorporating the fans into the performance would not only be a great way to engage them, but it would also create a sense of ownership and community among the audience. I think it would be particularly effective to have the dedicated fans participate in a special segment, maybe even a Q&A session or a jam session with the band. We could also consider offering exclusive rewards or perks to the fans who participate, such as a meet-and-greet or a signed merchandise package. What do you think about using some of the fan-generated content to create a social media campaign leading up to the performance? We could share some of the designs and ideas on our social media channels and encourage fans to share their own creations using a specific hashtag. It would be a great way to build anticipation and excitement for the show, and it would also give us a chance to showcase some of the amazing creativity and talent of our fans."

"I love that idea! The social media campaign could be a great way to create a buzz around the performance and get fans excited to participate. We could also use the hashtag to track the submissions and feature some of the best ones on our official social media accounts. Additionally, we could consider offering a prize for the most creative or innovative submission, such as a chance to meet the band or attend a private rehearsal. What do you think about incorporating some of the fan-generated content into the actual performance itself? For example, we could project some of the designs or artwork onto the stage or screens during the show, or even have the band play along with some of the fan-created music. It would be a great way to make the fans feel like they're an integral part of the performance."

"That's a fantastic idea! I can already imagine the excitement and engagement it would generate. We could also consider having a fan-generated content booth at the venue where people can create their submissions on the spot and share them instantly on social media. It would be a great way to encourage people to participate and share their experience with their friends and followers. Additionally, we could have a special 'fan spotlight' section on our website and social media channels where we feature the best submissions and give the fans who created them a shoutout. What do you think about partnering with a local art school or design program to help facilitate the fan-generated content and provide some guidance and resources for the fans who participate?"

"That sounds like a fantastic collaboration! I can already envision the creative and innovative ideas that the students from the art school or design program could bring to the table. We could also consider offering a special 'design challenge' where the students are tasked with creating a specific type of content, such as a logo or poster, that incorporates our brand and messaging. This would not only provide a fun and engaging experience for the fans, but also give the students a unique opportunity to showcase their skills and build their portfolios. What do you think about offering a prize or recognition for the winning design, such as a feature on our website or social media channels or even a chance to work with our team on a future project?"

"I love the idea of a design challenge! Offering a prize or recognition would definitely motivate the students to put in their best work. A feature on our website or social media channels would be a great way to showcase their talent, and the chance to work with our team on a future project would be a dream come true for many of them. We could also consider partnering with a local business or organization to provide an additional prize or recognition, such as a gift card or internship opportunity. What do you think about hosting a public vote or having our team select the winning design, and how would we handle any potential copyright or ownership issues?"

"I think a public vote would be a great way to engage the community and get more people involved in the design challenge. As for handling copyright and ownership issues, we could have a clear agreement in place that outlines the terms of use for the winning design, such as requiring the student to assign the rights to us or allowing them to retain the rights while still allowing us to use the design for promotional purposes. We could also consider having a panel of judges review the submissions and provide feedback to the students, which would not only help them improve their skills but also give us a better sense of the quality of the submissions. What are your thoughts on having a theme or specific design problem for the challenge, or would you rather leave it open-ended and let the students come up with their own ideas?"

"I like the idea of having a theme or specific design problem to focus the challenge and give students a clear direction. It would also allow us to tie the challenge to a specific community need or issue, which could make the outcome more impactful. For example, we could challenge students to design a solution for improving accessibility in public spaces or creating a more sustainable transportation system. Having a clear theme would also make it easier to promote the challenge and attract students who are interested in that specific area. What do you think about having a prize or recognition for the winning design, or would you rather focus on the process and learning experience for the students?"

"I think a prize or recognition for the winning design could be a great motivator for the students, but it's also important to emphasize the value of the learning experience and the process of designing and iterating. Perhaps we could offer a combination of both, where the winning design receives a prize, but all participating students receive recognition for their efforts and a chance to showcase their work. Additionally, we could consider partnering with local organizations or businesses to provide mentorship and feedback to the students, which could help them develop their skills and build connections in their field."

"This is a great idea, and I think it would be beneficial to also provide feedback to the students on their designs, not just the winning ones. We could have a panel of industry professionals or design experts review each submission and provide constructive criticism, which would not only help the students improve their skills but also give them a sense of accomplishment and pride in their work. Additionally, we could consider hosting a design showcase or exhibition where all the participating students can display their work, which would not only give them a chance to show off their talents but also provide an opportunity for them to network with potential employers and collaborators."

"This would not only benefit the students, but also provide a valuable resource for the industry professionals and experts who would be participating in the review process. It would give them a chance to see the latest trends and innovations in design, and potentially identify and mentor future talent. We could also consider offering a small prize or recognition for the students who receive the most feedback or show the most improvement over the course of the competition, to encourage them to keep pushing themselves and striving for excellence."

"This could be a win-win situation for everyone involved, as it would not only provide a unique learning opportunity for the students, but also allow the industry professionals to stay up-to-date with the latest design trends and potentially discover new talent. Additionally, we could also invite industry leaders to participate in a panel discussion or keynote presentation, sharing their insights and experiences with the students and providing a valuable networking opportunity."

"This would not only enhance the students' understanding of the design process, but also foster a sense of community and collaboration between the academic and professional worlds. Furthermore, we could also consider offering a design competition or challenge, where students would have the opportunity to showcase their skills and creativity, and industry professionals could provide feedback and guidance, helping to shape the next generation of designers."

"This would not only enhance the students' understanding of the design process, but also foster a sense of community and collaboration between the academic and professional worlds. Furthermore, we could also consider offering a design competition or challenge, where students would have the opportunity to showcase their skills and creativity, and industry professionals could provide feedback and guidance, helping to shape the next generation of designers. By doing so, we would be able to bridge the gap between education and industry, providing students with real-world experience and exposure to the latest design trends and technologies."
